examples.en: Because we have a lack of hands in our project, we have requested some help.
examples.ja: プロジェクトの人手が足りないので応援を要請しました。

examples.en: Unfortunately, Manager Tamura's request for additional workers was seemingly not accepted.
examples.ja: 残念ながら、田村マネージャーの追加人員要請は受理されなかったようです。

examples.en: The labor unions demanded a wage increase.
examples.ja: 労働組合は賃上げを要請した。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>need</kanji> something so you <kanji>request</kanji> it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What do you think made Tofugu take such a big leap forward this year?
examples.ja: トーフグが今年、大躍進を遂げたのは何故だと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>leap</kanji> and <kanji>advance</kanji>, you make <vocabulary>rapid progress</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>great advancement</vocabulary>.

You might recall that 飛躍 also means "rapid progress," but what sets them apart? 躍進 emphasizes the subject's perspective as it advances at a rapid pace, whereas 飛躍 conveys significant progress or leaps more neutrally, without highlighting pace or perspective.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Aya’s latest illustration of the Tofugu characters is very vibrant and lively.
examples.ja: アヤの最新のトーフグキャラのイラストは、とても躍動感に溢れています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Every <kanji>leap</kanji> you take is a <kanji>move</kanji> filled with <vocabulary>vibrancy</vocabulary>. Your <vocabulary>dynamic movement</vocabulary> captures the essence of <vocabulary>lively motion</vocabulary>, captivating all who witness it.

躍動 is not just about movement, but also about expressing internal vitality or liveliness through movements or actions. It’s commonly used as 躍動感 (a lively feeling).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I didn’t know it would be unlawful dumping.
examples.ja: それが不法投棄になるとは知らなかったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>throw</kanji> out something and <kanji>abandon</kanji> it, you are essentially <vocabulary>dumping</vocabulary> it.

投棄 is a formal word for <vocabulary>throwing away</vocabulary> things, often used in the context of illegally dumping waste.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

examples.en: I was rushing onto the last train, but the door closed before my eyes.
examples.ja: 終電に駆け込み乗車をしようとしましたが、目の前でドアが閉まりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
駆ける is "to gallop" and the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. To gallop into a place is <vocabulary>to rush into</vocabulary> it. You can’t gallop slowly, after all.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to seek refuge</vocabulary>, as in hurrying to a place for safety and support.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.

examples.en: When I asked him a question he just ran off.
examples.ja: 彼に質問を尋ねた時、駆け出しただけだ。

meaning_mnemonic: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going <vocabulary>to rush out</vocabulary> a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.

examples.en: The recipe said to put in saffron, so I ran around searching for it everywhere, but I couldn’t find any, so I didn’t add saffron this time.
examples.ja: レシピにサフランがいるって書いてあったから、あちこち駆け回って探したんだけど見つからなくて、結局今回はサフランは使わなかったの。

meaning_mnemonic: To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going <vocabulary>to run around</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.

examples.en: My mother called me a "disobedient child."
examples.ja: 母に「不孝者」と呼ばれた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 不孝 is "disobedience to parents"? Well, <kanji>someone</kanji> who shows <kanji>disobedience to parents</kanji> is a <vocabulary>disobedient child</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>unfilial child</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: 不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.

examples.en: It’s already too late, but I was a really disobedient son.
examples.ja: もう手遅れですが、私は本当に親不孝な息子でしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add <kanji>parent</kanji>s to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means <vocabulary>lack of filial piety</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>disobedience to parents</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.

examples.en: "May I use your cell phone?" "Sure, go ahead."
examples.ja: 「あなたの携帯電話をお借りしてもいいですか？」「ええ、どうぞ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a <vocabulary>portable phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cell phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone</vocabulary>. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.

examples.en: Once, a little while ago, 3D printers were cutting edge machines.
examples.ja: かつて、少し前までは、3Dプリンタは最新鋭の機械でした。

meaning_mnemonic: 最新 is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest <kanji>sharp</kanji> thing, is the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>state of the art</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Could you teach me what the SF and SH baseball terms mean?
examples.ja: 野球用語の犠飛と犠打の意味について教えてもらえませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> <kanji>fly</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sacrifice fly</vocabulary>. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 飛 just think about how <reading>he</reading> (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball <reading>he</reading>ated up.

examples.en: This is the girls locker room, which has opaque windows.
examples.ja: 不透明な窓がある女子の更衣室です。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is <vocabulary>opaque</vocabulary>, making this word <vocabulary>opacity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m slowly getting over my homesickness.
examples.ja: 徐々にホームシックを克服していってます。

meaning_mnemonic: Time to <kanji>overcome</kanji> the <kanji>clothes</kanji> of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I have detailed memories of the Chinese New Year from ten years ago.
examples.ja: 十年前の旧正月のことは、克明に覚えていますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>overcome</kanji> with <kanji>bright</kanji>ness, you'll be able to see all the little fine <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was too hyper when I arrived in Japan, wasn’t I?
examples.ja: 日本に到着した時、私はちょっとテンションが高すぎましたよね。

meaning_mnemonic: At the <kanji>arrival</kanji> time you will <kanji>arrive</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>arrival</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Is it a boy or a girl?" "They are actually twin boys."
examples.ja: 「男の子ですか？女の子ですか？」「実は双子の男の子なんです。」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>child</kanji>ren are the same as each other. They're <vocabulary>twins</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: My sister and I are fraternal twins, but we look very similar.
examples.ja: 妹と私は二卵性双生児ですが、外見がすごく似ています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a <vocabulary>pair</vocabulary>, you know?

examples.en: Do you have these binoculars in black?
examples.ja: この双眼鏡の黒はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>mirror</kanji>s - that's <vocabulary>binoculars</vocabulary>. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.
reading_mnemonic: The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, <reading>today</reading> (きょう)!

examples.en: He is a philosopher, but he isn’t a logical thinker.
examples.ja: 彼は哲学者だが、理路整然と考える人ではない。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>philosophy</kanji> <kanji>study</kanji> is the study of <vocabulary>philosophy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m very sorry but I’m afraid I can’t send a New Year’s card because I’m in mourning.
examples.ja: 大変申し訳ありませんが、喪に服しているため年賀状が送れないのです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What's the first two letters of the word <vocabulary>mourning</vocabulary>? It's <reading>mo</reading> (も). You can use that to remember.

examples.en: In the nursing home there is an old woman who seems to have lost her memory, but she is really funny.
examples.ja: 介護施設に、どうやら記憶喪失らしいお婆さんがいるんだけど、その人がすっごく面白いのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>mourning</kanji> your <kanji>fault</kanji>. Because of your fault, you have gotten a <vocabulary>loss</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>forfeit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think this prediction is pretty solid.
examples.ja: この予想は、かなり堅いと思うよ。

examples.en: As I thought, people who have serious jobs write in a serious way.
examples.ja: やっぱり堅い職業の人は、書く文章も堅いね。

examples.en: The recipe calls them delicious, moist cookies, but they turned out to be really hard.
examples.ja: レシピには、美味しくてしっとりしたクッキーって書いてあったのに、出来上がったクッキーはすっごく堅かったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>solid</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>upright</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>. This word is often used in the figurative sense, as in a solid defence, a serious topic, or an upright person.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Why did you enclose this sentence in brackets?
examples.ja: どうしてこの文章を括弧で括ったんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fasten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fasten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tie together</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You are fastening up the <reading>coocoo</reading> (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.

examples.en: In Japan they use a different method of measurement for baking sweets and cooking. I think it would be better to have one way of measuring throughout the world.
examples.ja: 日本では焼き菓子作りとか料理の計量方法が違うんだよね。いっそ世界中の計量方法が一括で同じだったらいいのにね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fasten</kanji> everything into <kanji>one</kanji>. <vocabulary>All together</vocabulary> in one <vocabulary>batch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lump</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened いち.

examples.en: We want people who have the ability to take a comprehensive view of things.
examples.ja: 物事を総括的にとらえる力がある人材がほしいんですよね。

examples.en: For starters, I'm going to begin with a summary of this year's activities.
examples.ja: まずは本年度の活動の総括から始めさせていただきます。

examples.en: Lastly, I'd like to sum up the project and discuss the challenges ahead.
examples.ja: 最後にプロジェクトを総括し、今後の課題について述べたいと思います。

examples.en: I summed up the information and reported it in order to alert my boss, but he was unwilling to listen.
examples.ja: 私は情報を総括し、上司の注意を促すために報告しましたが、彼は聞く耳を持ちませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you take the <kanji>whole</kanji> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together, you are <vocabulary>summing up</vocabulary> something and creating an <vocabulary>overview</vocabulary> of it.

総括 is a formal word you'll often come across in official meetings or reports. It means pulling together and summing up scattered bits of information — sometimes for a simple overview, like a department budget report, but more often for the sake of evaluating results and planning a future direction.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My father is responsible for unifying 100 subordinates at his company.
examples.ja: 父は会社では100人の部下を統括する責任者です。

examples.en: Is that guy the new general manager?
examples.ja: 新しく入った統括マネージャーってあいつのこと？

examples.en: We always disagree with the people in Risk Management.
examples.ja: 俺たちはいつもリスク統括部の奴らとは意見が合わないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Unite</kanji> something together and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it and you have <vocabulary>unification</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>generalization</vocabulary>. Nowadays this word is used to mean <vocabulary>management</vocabulary> in some contexts too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When people read the left bracket, they just say "kakko," but when they read the right bracket, they say "kakko-tojiru," which means "close bracket."
examples.ja: 左の括弧を読む時は単に「括弧」と言いますが、右の括弧を読む時は「括弧閉じる」と言います。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fasten</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji>s are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (<vocabulary>parentheses</vocabulary>) and [<vocabulary>brackets</vocabulary>].
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.

examples.en: The father ordered his son to paint an arc.
examples.ja: 父親は息子に円弧を描くように命令しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>round</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji> is, well, the shape of an <vocabulary>arc</vocabulary>. It has that round shape to it, you know?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He challenged the king to battle.
examples.ja: 彼は王に戦いを挑んだ。

examples.en: Next year, I'm planning to take on the JLPT N1.
examples.ja: 来年は、JLPTのN1に挑むつもりだ。

examples.en: You know what he's like, right? If it's for someone else's sake, he'll go up against anyone — even if he's got no shot of winning.
examples.ja: 知ってるだろ？アイツは、誰かのためなら、勝てない相手にでも挑むヤツだぜ。

examples.en: I'm going to challenge the famous bacon connoisseur this Sunday.
examples.ja: 私はこの日曜日、有名なベーコン鑑定家に挑みます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with a う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>challenge</kanji>, and the verb form means <vocabulary>to challenge someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take on something difficult</vocabulary>. 

挑む is a relatively formal word for boldly facing a challenge. It has a strong, spirited feel, like a climber saying "I'm taking on Mt. Everest!" You'll come across it in headlines, live sports commentary, anime battle scenes, or even in daily life when someone wants to sound determined and fired up about their big personal goal.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>I do</reading>n't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my <reading>Id</reading> (いど), after all.

examples.en: I want to try taking on a new job.
examples.ja: 新しい仕事に挑戦してみたいんです。

examples.en: Our mom is currently competing in a cooking contest.
examples.ja: うちの母は今、料理コンテストに挑戦中です。

examples.en: Huh, you dare challenge me? You've got a death wish.
examples.ja: ハッ、俺に挑戦する気か？命知らずだな。

examples.en: No way! You really are such an airhead. Why are you attempting to mimic a cicada's shrilling?
examples.ja: ありえねえ！お前ってほんと、超天然キャラだよな。なんで蝉の鳴き真似に挑戦なんてしてるんだよ？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>challenge</kanji> for <kanji>war</kanji>? This is <vocabulary>a challenge</vocabulary> worth accepting. After all, we can't give up without at least giving it <vocabulary>a try</vocabulary> or making some kind of <vocabulary>an attempt</vocabulary>.

Note that 挑戦 refers to a challenge not in the sense of a difficult, challenging task, but in the sense of a bold or daring attempt to take on that task — whether that's defeating a formidable foe, performing an impressive feat, or tackling a tricky problem.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A protester threw a Molotov cocktail toward the police during a riot to provoke them.
examples.ja: 抗議者の一人が、警察を挑発するために火炎瓶を投げつけました。

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>challenge</kanji> has made a <kanji>departure</kanji> and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a <vocabulary>provocation</vocabulary> to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Kumaman is a middle-aged, widower living and digging gold like his father before him.
examples.ja: クママンは中年の男やもめで、家業で金を掘っています。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dig</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you are going <vocabulary>to dig</vocabulary> you are going to end up making a <reading>ho</reading>le (ほ).

examples.en: Would you like to do a part-time job in fossil excavation? It'll be fun!
examples.ja: 化石発掘のバイトをしてみませんか。楽しいですよ！

examples.en: Until about 30 years ago, iron ore could be found in this mine.
examples.ja: この鉱山では三十年ほど前まで鉄鉱石が発掘できました。

examples.en: The talent was discovered through a star search audition.
examples.ja: そのタレントはスター発掘オーディションで発掘されました。

examples.en: One day, he excavated a large number of old Greek treasures while digging for gold.
examples.ja: ある日、金を求めて穴を掘っていると、大量の古代ギリシャのお宝を発掘しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Let's <kanji>departure</kanji> on our <kanji>dig</kanji>ging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an <vocabulary>excavation</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.

examples.en: I’m just about to deep fry pork cutlets.
examples.ja: ちょうど今からトンカツを揚げるところです。

examples.en: These days, we don't see many houses raising the Japanese flag during public holidays.
examples.ja: 最近は祝日に日本の国旗を揚げる家をあまり見ませんね。

examples.en: It's actually quite a bit of work to hoist a sail on a yacht.
examples.ja: ヨットのセイルを揚げるのって結構大変なんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hoist</kanji>. But most commonly (and most importantly), this word means <vocabulary>to deep fry</vocabulary>. I guess you can think of it as hoisting that delicious deep-fried food out of the oil.

Of course, 揚げる can also mean <vocabulary>to hoist</vocabulary> (a sail) or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> (a flag) depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

examples.en: Since you make rice balls by pressing rice, it's called "onigiri."
examples.ja: おにぎりは、ご飯を握って作るので「お握り」と呼ばれています。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go <vocabulary>to grasp</vocabulary> someone. You really need them. You are soooo <reading>needy</reading> (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.

examples.en: I bought a CD that came with two handshake tickets as a bonus. (Handshake tickets are similar to meet and greet tickets.)
examples.ja: CDを買うと、オマケで握手券が二枚ついてきた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>grip</kanji> with your <kanji>hand</kanji> (onto another hand) is a <vocabulary>handshake</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.

examples.en: I haven't done any housework in a while because I have terrible morning sickness.

meaning_mnemonic:
When you do something <kanji>temporarily</kanji>, you're only doing it <vocabulary>for a while</vocabulary>. It's not permanent — however long it lasts, it's just <vocabulary>for some time</vocabulary>.

暫く refers to a stretch of time that's not too long, but not super short either — just somewhere in between. How long, exactly? It kinda depends on the speaker. If it feels like a while to you, then hey, it's a while!

Keep in mind that the kanji form is quite formal, so it's more commonly written in kana, like しばらく.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've been waiting <vocabulary>for a while</vocabulary> and nothing has happened yet, so you start singing a <reading>shee</reading>p <reading>balla</reading>d (しばら). This ballad helps you sleep by counting sheep. If you manage to doze off <vocabulary>for some time</vocabulary>, time will surely pass faster, and then something might happen!

枢軸 is generally used figuratively to describe the <vocabulary>central part</vocabulary> of something important, or the center of power.

examples.en: Let's meet up at the intersection of the earth's axis and the celestial sphere in the Arctic.
examples.ja: 地軸の延長が北方で天球と交わる点で会いましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Literally, 軸 can refer to a physical <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary>, like the shaft something rotates around. Figuratively, it describes the <vocabulary>pivotal part</vocabulary> of something, like the central figure in a project, the core idea of a discussion, or the core belief that shapes who you are.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I want Aya to paint a picture for the hanging scroll.
examples.ja: アヤに、掛軸のための絵を描いてもらいたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: It <kanji>hang</kanji>s on an <kanji>axis</kanji> point. The axis opens up, and reveals a <vocabulary>hanging scroll</vocabulary>. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
reading_mnemonic: For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.

examples.en: I thought something was wrong with the car, and sure enough, they found a problem with the wheel's central axis area.

examples.en: How you live changes depending on what you choose to center your life around.
examples.ja: 人生の中軸をどこに置くかで、生き方が変わる。

examples.en:
Hmm, in this machine, the central axis here might be a little off.
Even a slight wobble in the axis can throw off the balance of the whole thing.
examples.ja: うーん、この機械、ここの中軸が少しずれているのかもしれませんね。中軸がちょっとでもぶれると、全体のバランスがおかしくなってくるんですよ。

examples.en: Last night I had a dream about a coral polyp's axial skeleton.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>axis</kanji> is where the <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary> is, of course, but it's also where the <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> is too.

examples.en: Don’t judge people’s personalities by their appearance like you’d judge a book by its cover.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>pattern</kanji> is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their <vocabulary>personal character</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>char</kanji>, but the verb version is <vocabulary>to get burned</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get scorched</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to get charred</vocabulary>.

This is for when something is burned on the surface. Most of the time, 焦げる is the unhappy and accidental kind of burning. You can use 焦げる when your bread is burned in the toaster, for example, or a shirt is scorched and blackened by an iron.
reading_mnemonic: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a <reading>子</reading> (こ). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means <vocabulary>chutzpah</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary> (besides just being <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary>). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary> isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you <reading>chemo</reading> (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.

examples.en: The hepatitis A patient is starving for love and always tries to get attention from the nurses and doctors.
examples.ja: あのA型肝炎の患者は愛に飢えており、いつも医者や看護師の気を引こうとしている。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have the ol' <kanji>liver</kanji> <kanji>flame</kanji> then you probably have <vocabulary>hepatitis</vocabulary>. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "If all the food in the world ran out and you were really hungry, would you eat my liver?" "Hmm, Dunno." "What do you mean you dunno?" "I just don’t know right now."
examples.ja: 「もし世界中の食料が無くなって、お前がすっげぇお腹がすいてるとしたら、俺の肝臓、食べるか？」「さあ、どうだろう。」「さあ、どうだろうって、それ、どういう意味だよ。」「今は分かんないってこと。」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>liver</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is your <vocabulary>liver</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Did you water the lawn for me?
examples.ja: 芝に水は撒いてくれた？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Walking on the lawn in this park is prohibited.
examples.ja: この公園では、芝生の上を歩くのは禁止されています。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lawn</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji> is just your <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary>. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.

examples.en: The email from Toshiba's customer center was all garbled.
examples.ja: 東芝のお客様センターから届いたメールは、全文文字化けしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>lawn</kanji> isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company <vocabulary>Toshiba</vocabulary>. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
reading_mnemonic: This word combines the on'yomi for 東 and the kun'yomi you learned with 芝. You can just think of the meaning (Toshiba) to remember the readings here, so you should be good to go.

examples.en: The turf in these turf cookies gives them their green color.
examples.ja: この芝草が、芝草クッキーを緑色にしてくれるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>lawn</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>turf</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!

examples.en: My first boyfriend always had a stuffy nose and would breathe hard when we talked on the phone.
examples.ja: 私の初めての彼氏はいつも鼻が詰まっていて、電話をする時は息づかいが荒かったです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>wild</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.

examples.en: My hands will be rough as long as I’m a beauty artist, there’s nothing I can do about it.
examples.ja: 美容師として働いている限りは、手が荒れるのはどうしようもありません。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>wild</kanji> and the verb is <vocabulary>to be stormy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be rough</vocabulary>. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I sewed a bag for my kid to use at school.
examples.ja: 子どもが学校で使う用の袋を縫いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a <vocabulary>sack</vocabulary> and move on to the next item.

examples.en: The train station staff told me that I’m required to use a carrying case in order to take a bicycle onto the train, but I’m wondering if I could use a garbage bag for it.
examples.ja: 駅員さんに、電車に自転車を持ち込む場合は、持ち運び用の袋の使用が義務づけられているって言われたんだけど、代わりにゴミ袋を使っちゃだめなのかなぁ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>garbage</kanji> (ゴミ) <kanji>sack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>garbage sack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>garbage bag</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.

examples.en: On New Year’s Day my sister and I woke up 4 a.m. to line up to buy Lucky Bags.
examples.ja: 元旦に、福袋を買う列に並ぶため、妹と私は朝の四時に起きました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mystery bag</vocabulary>. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as <vocabulary>mystery sack</vocabulary>s as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 福 and 袋, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I think I want to do something to show my filial piety toward my parents.
examples.ja: 何か両親に親孝行してあげたいと思っています。

examples.en: You should at least do something nice for your mom on Mother's Day!
examples.ja: 母の日くらいは親孝行しようよ！

examples.en: Perhaps true filial piety is spending time with your parents, not spending money on them.
examples.ja: お金じゃなくて、時間を使って一緒に過ごすのが本当の親孝行かもしれない。

examples.en: But isn't the age of robots honoring our parents for us just around the corner?
examples.ja: でも、もうすぐロボットが代わりに親孝行してくれる時代が来るんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic:
You have the kanji for <kanji>parent</kanji> combined with 孝行, which you know means "filial piety." If you show filial piety toward your parents… well, it's still <vocabulary>filial piety</vocabulary>. Now it's just extra clear who you're showing that filial devotion to! 

While it may feel kind of redundant, 親孝行 tends to be a little more common than 孝行. It's nice to add "parent" for extra love points, you know?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

examples.en: She chuckled when she saw my new hairstyle. That’s rude, isn’t it?
examples.ja: 俺の新しい髪型を見て、あいつプッと吹き出したんだぜ。失礼だよな。

meaning_mnemonic: If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need <vocabulary>to begin to blow</vocabulary> to do that!
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 吹く and 出す.

examples.en: The reality is that the house is so old that the rain and wind blows in whenever a storm comes.
examples.ja: 家はおんぼろで、嵐が来る度に雨風が吹き込むのが現実です。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 吹く is "to blow" and the kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>. So this word means <vocabulary>to blow in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to breathe into</vocabulary>, and it can be used both transitively and intransitively.

It can also be used figuratively to mean to breathe into or<vocabulary>to imbue</vocabulary>, like breathing new life into something, or imbuing someone’s mind with hatred.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 吹く and the kanji 込む.

examples.en: What attracts you to whistling?
examples.ja: 口笛を吹くことにどんな魅力を感じますか。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're <kanji>blow</kanji>ing your whistle you're going <vocabulary>to whistle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.

examples.en: This miso soup is too salty. Can you water down a little bit?
examples.ja: この味噌汁はしょっぱすぎるよ。もうちょっと薄めてもらってもいいかな？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dilute</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dilute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to water down</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

examples.en: I’m thinking about how to escape from zombies if they actually showed up.
examples.ja: 万が一ゾンビが実際に現れた場合を想定して、どうやってゾンビから逃れるのかを考えているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
reading_mnemonic: This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Let’s go to the party and brush off your depression.
examples.ja: パーティーに行って、憂鬱なんて吹き飛ばしちゃおうぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going <vocabulary>to blow away</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.

examples.en: This actor is popular with everyone.
examples.ja: この俳優は、万人に人気がある。

examples.en: In any case, wouldn't it be better to go with a design that appeals to everyone?
examples.ja: やっぱり万人受けするデザインにする方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: This seems to be the common impression among everyone.
examples.ja: これは万人に共通の感想だろう。

meaning_mnemonic: If we're talking about <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>s, then we might as well be talking about <vocabulary>all people</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary>, because that's a lot of people, you know?
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 万 and 人 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

<vocabulary>All people</vocabulary> have been <reading>ban</reading>ned from <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (ばんにん). Apparently they're working on something super secret, so now <vocabulary>everybody</vocabulary> is banned. What could it be?!

examples.en: We can't let the criminal escape.
examples.ja: あの犯人を逃がすことはできない。

examples.en: I've infiltrated this facility to set free the hostages who are being held here.
examples.ja: この施設に捕らえられている人質を逃がすために潜入しました。

examples.en: He was a real sitting duck, but we let him go.
examples.ja: いいカモだったのに、逃がしちゃったね。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know how 逃げる means "to escape"? This is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to let someone escape</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to let someone go</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to set someone free</vocabulary>. You know this because you'd want to let everyone escape when the place is filled with gas (がす).

逃がす is often about purposely letting someone or something go — like setting a bird free or letting a captive escape quietly. But it can also be used in more unintentional and regretful situations, like failing to catch a criminal or missing a big opportunity.
reading_mnemonic:
You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる but here’s another mnemonic to help you remember:

You decided <vocabulary>to let someone escape</vocabulary> because they were on their <reading>knee</reading>s (に) begging you to set them free.

examples.en: She's small, but full of energy.
examples.ja: 彼女は小柄だけど、とても元気です。

examples.en: Petite people just somehow seem more approachable, don't they?
examples.ja: 小柄な人って、なんとなく親しみやすいよね。

examples.en: At that store, there was a little old lady doing her shopping.
examples.ja: その店では、一人の小柄なおばあさんが買い物をしていた。

examples.en: He shook his small body as he laughed, but his laughter made no sound.
examples.ja: 小柄な体を揺らして、彼は笑ったが、その笑いには音がなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone built from a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>pattern</kanji> has a <vocabulary>small build</vocabulary>. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Her hand was so white it was almost transparent.
examples.ja: 彼女の手は透き通るほど白かった。

examples.en: The water is very clear and beautiful.
examples.ja: 水が透き通っていてきれい。

examples.en: Once the onions become transparent, add the meat.
examples.ja: 玉ねぎが透き通ってきたら肉を入れてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>transparent</kanji> enough for things (like light) to <kanji>pass through</kanji> is going <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary>. In other words, it's going <vocabulary>to be clear</vocabulary>.

Unlike 透ける, which is more for things that are partially transparent due to being thin or sheer, 透き通る describes things that are totally transparent, clear, or pure — think glass, water, a cloudless sky, or even a clear and pure voice.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I hope the cucumber pickles turn out tasty when they're done pickling.
examples.ja: キュウリの漬物、美味しく漬かるといいな。

examples.en: The daikon radish should be well pickled by now, so you can take it out.
examples.ja: 大根はもう漬かってるはずだから、出していいよ。

examples.en: This eggplant has been pickled very well. It's soaked up the flavor and tastes delicious!
examples.ja: このナス、しっかり漬かってるね。味がしみてて美味しい！

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something." When it becomes 漬かる, it means the food has reached a state where the pickling or marinating process is complete, and it's ready to eat. So this word means <vocabulary>to be well pickled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be well marinated</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.

examples.en: This is my first time eating salmon ramen.
examples.ja: 鮭拉麺なんて初めて食べるよ。

examples.en: What small companies need in order to grow is ramen.
examples.ja: 小さな会社が成長するのに必要なのは、拉麺です。

examples.en: I spilled ramen soup on my crotch.
examples.ja: 股間に拉麺の汁をこぼしてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you're going to <kanji>abduct</kanji> some <kanji>noodles</kanji>, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, <vocabulary>ramen</vocabulary>! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you <kanji>pull</kanji> the dough to stretch it when you make <vocabulary>ramen noodles</vocabulary>. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!

This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺 or ラー麺.
reading_mnemonic: Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long らー, just think how excited you are about these ramen! <reading>Raaaaaa</reading>! Raaaamen! So exciting!

examples.en: Everyone started slurping down the cold somen.
examples.ja: みんな冷たい素麺をツルツル食べ始めました。

examples.en: The taste of the soup is lighter because the somen noodles are added at the end.
examples.ja: 最後に素麺を入れるのでスープの味は薄めになっています。

examples.en: Mami made us somen that she'd brought from Japan.
examples.ja: マミさんが日本から持ってきた素麺を作ってくれた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you can read this word, you may well know what it means. It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>somen noodles</vocabulary>, which are <vocabulary>fine white noodles</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because <vocabulary>somen</vocabulary> are your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) food.

examples.en: When eating mochi, all of my relatives put mayonnaise on it.
examples.ja: 私の親戚はみんな餅にマヨネーズをかけて食べます。

examples.en: His suitcase was filled with nothing but mochi.
examples.ja: 彼のスーツケースには餅しか入ってなかった。

examples.en: I ordered the mochi and green tea set.
examples.ja: お餅と緑茶のセットを頼みました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. <kanji>Mochi</kanji> is <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, <vocabulary>mochi</vocabulary> is <reading>mochi</reading> (もち)!

examples.en: The use of insecticides is strictly prohibited on this farm.
examples.ja: この農場では殺虫剤の使用は厳禁です。

examples.en: Pesticides are dangerous if they enter the human body.
examples.ja: 殺虫剤は人体に入ると危険です。

examples.en: Because fireflies are insects, they are vulnerable to cold and insecticides.
examples.ja: 蛍は昆虫なので、寒さや殺虫剤に弱い。

meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>kill</kanji>s <kanji>insect</kanji>s with one <kanji>dose</kanji>? That's an <vocabulary>insecticide</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>pesticide</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'd like to know the opinions of both sides, not just one.
examples.ja: 片方だけでなく、双方の意見が知りたいですね。

examples.en: Marriage requires the consent of both parties.
examples.ja: 結婚には双方の合意が必要です。

examples.en: Both sides' claims are no closer to being reconciled.
examples.ja: 双方の主張は平行線をたどっています。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've got a <kanji>pair</kanji> of <kanji>direction</kanji>s, so this is something that concerns <vocabulary>both parties</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>. Things are going in two directions, not just one! 

双方 is a relatively formal term that is often used in contexts like <vocabulary>mutual</vocabulary> agreements, negotiations, or discussions where both sides are actively engaged.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I love kimchi fried rice.
examples.ja: 私はキムチ炒飯が大好きです。

examples.en: I'll go with the fried rice.
examples.ja: 俺は炒飯にするよ。

examples.en: Making delicious fried rice isn't easy.
examples.ja: 美味しい炒飯を作るのは簡単じゃない。

meaning_mnemonic:
What's your favorite <kanji>fry</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji>? Surely it's <vocabulary>fried rice</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>chahan</vocabulary>! Who doesn't love fried rice?

Note that this word is commonly written in katakana as チャーハン, so you may also see it written that way on a menu or product label!
reading_mnemonic:
You know the reading for 飯, but 炒 uses an exceptional reading that you didn't learn. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Do you know what would bring your <vocabulary>fried rice</vocabulary> to the next level? Some <reading>char</reading>coal (ちゃー)! Next time, just add a little charcoal to your fried rice, and it'll taste so much better. Trust me on this one.

examples.en: That singer's outfits are always flashy.
examples.ja: あの歌手の衣装はいつも派手です。

examples.en: Is there a costume rental shop around here?
examples.ja: この辺にレンタル衣装屋さんってある？

examples.en: I'm sorry! I had a little trouble changing into the next costume.
examples.ja: すみません！次の衣装に着替えるのに、少し手こずってしまって。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Clothes</kanji> and <kanji>attire</kanji> makes this <vocabulary>clothing</vocabulary> at its core, but these days, it usually refers to <vocabulary>stage outfit</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>costume</vocabulary>s for performances and public events.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. While you've learned these for both of the kanji, 装 actually uses one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know whose wardrobe was definitely full of special <vocabulary>clothing</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>costume</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>outfit</vocabulary>s? The <reading>sho</reading>gun's (しょう)! Know all those old-timey looking paintings of shoguns in their regal attire? Just think of that when you have to remember this reading for 装!

examples.en: On weekends, the shopping mall bustles with shoppers.
examples.ja: ショッピングモールは週末、買い物客で賑わう。

examples.en: Every year, the festivals and fireworks draw lively crowds of people.
examples.ja: 毎年、祭りも花火大会も大勢の人で賑わいます。

examples.en: That cilantro specialty restaurant in the alley over there seems to be doing quite well.
examples.ja: あそこの路地にあるパクチー料理専門レストラン、中々賑わってるらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>bustling</kanji> or <kanji>lively</kanji>, so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be bustling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lively</vocabulary>.

賑わう is typically used to describe bustling places or times. You might see it in phrases like 若者で賑わう街 (streets bustling with young people) or 夏に観光客で賑わう (to be crowded with tourists in summer). Since bustling places tend to flourish economically, it can also carry a nuance of prosperity and mean <vocabulary>to thrive</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the reading you learned with 賑, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: My family is lively.
examples.ja: うちの家族は賑やかです。

examples.en: With a new child due in November, we're expecting to have a lively Christmas this year.
examples.ja: １１月には子供が増えて、今年のクリスマスは賑やかになる予定です。

examples.en: What with radio calisthenics for the elderly going on and all, the park was really bustling this morning.
examples.ja: 午前中の公園は老人向けのラジオ体操もあってかなり賑やかでしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This shares meanings with the kanji, making it <vocabulary>bustling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lively</vocabulary>.

You might see 賑やか used to describe bustling and crowded city streets, a festive celebration, the sound of boisterous laughter, or even just a cheerful, animated person.
reading_mnemonic: This uses the reading you learned with 賑, so you should be good to go here!
